title.text: Identifying the Semantic Orientation of Foreign Words

entities.text: Identifying the Semantic Orientation of Foreign Words

abstractContent.text: We present a method for identifying the positive or negative semantic orientation of foreign words.

entities.text: identifying the positive or negative semantic orientation of foreign words

abstractContent.text: Identifying the semantic orientation of words has numerous applications in the areas of text classification, analysis of product review, analysis of responses to surveys, and mining online discussions.

entities.text: Identifying the semantic orientation of words

abstractContent.text: Identifying the semantic orientation of English words has been extensively studied in literature.

entities.text: Identifying the semantic orientation of English words

abstractContent.text: Most of this work assumes the existence of resources (e.g. Wordnet, seeds, etc) that do not exist in foreign languages.
In this work, we describe a method based on constructing a multilingual network connecting English and foreign words.
We use this network to identify the semantic orientation of foreign words based on connection between words in the same language as well as multilingual connections.
The method is experimentally tested using a manually labeled set of positive and negative words and has shown very promising results .

introductionContent.text: A great body of research work has focused on identifying the semantic orientation of words.

entities.text: identifying the semantic orientation of words

introductionContent.text: Word polarity is a very important feature that has been used in several applications.
For example, the problem of mining product reputation from Web reviews has been extensively studied.

entities.text: mining product reputation from Web reviews

introductionContent.text: This is a very important task given the huge amount of product reviews written on the Web and the difficulty of manually handling them.
Another interesting application is mining attitude in discussions ( , where the attitude of participants in a discussion is inferred using the text they exchange.
Due to its importance, several researchers have addressed the problem of identifying the semantic orientation of individual words.

entities.text: identifying the semantic orientation of individual words

introductionContent.text: This work has almost exclusively focused on English.
Most of this work used several language dependent resources.
For example use the entire English Web corpus by submitting queries consisting of the given word and a set of seeds to a search engine.
In addition, several other methods have used Wordnet for connecting semantically related words (.
When we try to apply those methods to other languages, we run into the problem of the lack of resources in other languages when compared to English.
For example, the General Inquirer lexicon () has thousands of English words labeled with semantic orientation.
Most of the literature has used it as a source of labeled seeds or for evaluation.
Such lexicons are not readily available in other languages.
Another source that has been widely used for this task is Wordnet.
Even though other Wordnets have been built for other languages, their coverage is very limited when compared to the English Wordnet.
In this work, we present a method for predicting the semantic orientation of foreign words.

entities.text: predicting the semantic orientation of foreign words

introductionContent.text: The pro-592 posed method is based on creating a multilingual network of words that represents both English and foreign words.
The network has English-English connections, as well as foreign-foreign connections and English-foreign connections.
This allows us to benefit from the richness of the resources built for the English language and in the meantime utilize resources specific to foreign languages.
shows a multilingual network where a sparse foreign network and a dense English network are connected.

We then define a random walk model over the multilingual network and predict the semantic orientation of any given word by comparing the mean hitting time of a random walk starting from it to a positive and a negative set of seed English words.
We use both Arabic and Hindi for experiments.
We compare the performance of several methods using the foreign language resources only and the multilingual network that has both English and foreign words.
We show that bootstrapping from languages with dense resources such as English is useful for improving the performance on other languages with limited resources.
The rest of the paper is structured as follows.
In section 2, we review some of the related prior work.
We define our problem and explain our approach in Section 3.
Results and discussion are presented in Section 4.
We conclude in Section 5.
